												An old school space sim with new mechanics.Strike Suit Zero is one of the early titles developped for the Oculus Rift but if you aren't that lucky yet, don't worry this game is still great.The universe is very immersive, with it's great open spaces and impressive color palette, the game is visually striking. But it does not end there, there is full support for any type of control method (Mouse+Keyboard, Gamepad, Joystick+Keyboard, HOTAS) and the button mapping is really intuitive (just be sure to select Joystick+Keyboard when playing with a HOTAS). However, when it comes to controlling ships, there's not much to choose from. Being a recruit you'll start with a standard fighter then shortly after you'll unlock the Strike Suit and further down some other 2 ships bringing it to a total of four ships to choose from, which is not much. But the game being named Strike Suit Zero, you already guessed what the main ship will be. It's main feature is that is can transform into a Transformer like mech and fire lock on missiles and heavy caliber both using Flux as energy, this Flux can be regenerated over time and be destroying enemy targets. So yeah, it's pretty badass. But the game does not let you be badass for long as the didfficulty of missions ramp up very quickly and the ally AI is utterly useless, forcing you to always be at your best to triumph. The old school difficulty also applies to the ranking system, if you do as you are told you might get a medal, but if you do everyones job you'll earn silver or gold. Keep in mind that there is Platinum above and since you've already won the battle to yourself there is not much left to do!Anyway, besides its frustrating difficulty Strike Suit Zero is a fantastic experience and a worthy one if you want to prepare for StarCitizen later this year (press time). With it's challenging but rewarding gameplay, this is a game that I recommend.

												Strike suit zero is one of the first games to be funded by kickstarter. It is perhaps the best game I've played which integrates the mechanics of transforming a plane into a humanoid mecha in sace.In its completed state I would say that it is more like a proof of concept than a full game. The game is quite short, with only 13 missions, and no multiplayer. The difficulty curve of the game increases rapidly, but this is due to difficulties with completing the objectives/targeting the correct enemy. Yes, targeting is quite a nightmare, early in the game when there are fewer enemies, SSZ's targetting system works flawlessly. However as you progress later in the game where enemies swarm down on your fleet, it becomes an uphill battle to find the crucial enemy targets and hunt them down before they destroy your capital ships. However, when everything works smoothly and you seamlessly integrate pursuit (plane) mode with strike (mecha) mode to hunt down targets, you will feel like a complete badd ♥♥♥ ace out of Macross.TLDR/If you're dying to fulfill your fantisies of being a valkyrie pilot from Macross try SSZ then go ahead and buy the game, I look forward to Born Ready Games continuining with this IP to make more and more awesome games. er 23, 2015
A dogfight space-sim. As pretty alright as the soundtrack is and as pretty as it looks it's not a very big game, the story's not exactly the most engaging out there, and there are only 13 pretty-short missions to go through. The mission objectives themselves are all generally the same protect-this & destroy-these missions so it can be repetitious.When it comes to the base gameplay they work and control great. The combat can get pretty intense the more enemies you're up against especially when suddenly your targets are large fleets themselves with guns covering practically every surface its got and the sudden priority is to take out the things that fire back.Surviving involves you keeping your ship's armor (health) and regenerating shield up and as far as I know there's no way of repairing your ship's armor without reloading a checkpoint or getting it repaired when told in one particular mission. The reload-checkpoint-to-recover-everything deal looked to me like an exploitable mechanic of sorts even though there aren't very many checkpoints throughout the game, especially the later missions with their longer mission times and limited amount of checkpoints.Each mission has an optional objective you can do that will unlock an upgrade but each one are just shared stat upgrades for all of the ships you have. What you're to do and what you can unlock are shown in the mission select screen upon preparing for the mission chosen. New ships and weapons are unlocked through progress of the missions.After a few missions you'll eventually unlock the "Strike Suit" ship which basically transforms into a straight-up mech (Strike Mode) if the "Flux" bar it comes with is filled enough through received or given damage. It's able to move more relatively freely in the three dimensions its got, has a very capable auto-locking targeting system on chosen targets within distance, and can target & lock-on to large numbers of targets for use of the barrage of the seeking missiles it can fire. The Flux bar starts to drain upon use of Strike Mode's firing capabilities but if used efficiently the Flux bar can prolong its usage without transforming back to ship mode.Kind of surprisingly the Strike Suit you use is the only mech in the game. No ally or enemy has anything similar although the mech may as well just be a temporary ship with a few more capabilities.There's not a whole lot else to this game outside of the well-done space-dogfighting.

y 3, 2016
												This game is a lot like Freespace 1 and 2. Basically, if you took those games and gave them a modern engine, it would be this. The only big difference (so far) is that after a few missions, you get the Strike Suit, which can either fly (when it's in ship mode) or hold relatively still and fight (in robot mode). Robot mode lets you turn a lot quicker, and it can lock onto lots of targets at once. Highly useful. However, the game (so far) doesn't have some of the stuff I miss from Freespace, like missiles designed to take out specific ship systems. Pretty good for an inexpensive game.I feel like there are a lot of keys to memorize, but it's easier if you keep your left hand on ASDF.

ry 25
												I have not played other space flight simulators extensively, so I cannot review this game based on how it compares to others in the genre. I can say that the graphics, controls, and level design do deliver on one thing - immersion.When you're making a hard turn, going upside down to try and flank the ship on your tail, the tension is real, as is the feeling in the back of your mind that you are travelling through endless, empty space. When another computer controlled ship in your squadron swings by and bails you out of something or steals your kill, it feels like a real, chaotic dogfight.Possibly the most important immersive part of the game is, once you unlock the Strike Suit, how much it really does look and feel like you are piloting a Gundam. When you first get it, with the music playing in the background and all of the swarms of enemy ships, you completely annhilate almost everything you can see. Then, in the next mission, the learning curve picks up, and you start to feel the limitations of this awesome machine. Quickly, because of how powerful the strike suit is, you get thrown into messes that are too much for the ship alone, and you have to knuckle down and enhance your skills to keep up. Meanwhile, the war rages on, and its emotional toll is felt by all.Doesn't that sound just like the plot of most Gundam shows? I was impressed by how the designers used their game's difficulty curve to reinforce the feel of being that one pilot with the super weapon on whom everything depends. This game is pretty hard, or at least it was for me, and as the best hard games do, it pushed me to get better and really hunker down to get specials from the missions so that I was well equipped enough to handle later ones.The story is nothing to write home about, and some of the combat scenarios get repetitive, especially since you often have to replay missions to get power ups. But the overall atmosphere of the game? Superb. And that makes playing it a joy, even if part of you is thinking 'torpedos? Again?'

er 15, 2013
												A game from a tiny developer with a successful kickstarter project, Strike Suit Zero is an accomplishment I'm sure many will remember. What this game lacks in complexity, it more than makes up for elsewhere. If anything, all you can really complain about is that it feels as though there's just not enough of it! So you want to know what this game is, what it does, etc. Well, imagine for one moment if the RTS game Homeworld, was smooshed together with the TV series Battlestar Galactica, the pacing of Super R-Type, the mecha styling of Mobile Suit Gundam, the atmosphere and vibrance of Zone of the Enders and infused with the soul of the X3 series. Now imagine that all of that comes together in an orgy of frenetic 3d-space combat, beautiful, vibrant graphics, a challenging AI, a good selection of ships/mecha and weapons and a soundtrack reminiscent of the musical stylings of Talvin Singh.Bottom Line : If you love your twitch gaming, but also want an atmospheric, challenging, not to mention stunning, 3d space shooter with an engaging story and an AI that'll keep you on your toes, then look no further. This really is a gem, and at under a fiver on steam, you've really got no excuses if this kind of thing is your cup of tea!Overall : 9/10Audio : 9/10Graphics : 9/10Gameplay : 9/10

17, 2014
												A long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away, there was FreeSpace2. This Space Combat Sim became arguably the best in the genre. Sadly, when FS2 came out in 1999 the Space Combat Sim genre was slowly dying. It was the last of an era and no others that came after could hold a candle to it. I played thousands of hours on FreeSpace 2 and the various fan made mods for over a decade, all the while wishing for someone to come revive the genre with a game worthy of FS2's legacy. And it wasn't until 2013 that my wish came true with the release of STRIKE SUIT ZERO.STRIKE SUIT ZERO - CONTROLS -- The game gives Space Sim enthusiasts the ship control they crave while giving the casual player easy mouse control. After the first mission I was digging around in my closet for my old Saitek x36 Flight controller. Mapping controls was easy enough, but be careful if your rudder is messed up. Axis Z is hard coded to menu navigation and could make mission and craft selection a pain. I would hightly suggest turning up your X/Y Axis sensitivity as the default setting makes your fighter move like an overloaded freighter. GAMEPLAY -- The missions feel like those from FreeSpace, my meaning being your not the focus of the fight. Epic battles are being waged around you. You are only a small cog in the machine, as it should be. You have specific objectives assigned to you while other units perform their duties. There are only four ships to chose from in SST, but I did not find the selection lacking. They were easy to customize to my flight style though the use of weapon load-outs (which remind me of the load-outs you could pick in Freespace, just with fewer choices). SST adds its own interesting twist to the genre with the "Strike Suit", a craft that has the ability to transform into a mech like something out of an anime. At first I thought this was going to be a cheesy gimmick-like easy button, but I was pleasantly surprised. The strike suit mode was not overly powered and did require a decent amount of skill to use effectively. You have to charge the strike suit though "FLUX", which can be gained by dishing out damage or less so though damage received. Your weapons in Strike Mode use up FLUX and once it is used up your ship is reverted back to interceptor mode.CONS: The game is woefully short. I would have liked to see multiple campaigns and possibly a co-op mode. Also, you have no control over your wing-men. In my honest opinion that would have made the game better for me. However, this is just nit-picking. The game is awesome. Anyone who has played FS2, I highly suggest this game to you. When Born Ready boasts that SSZ is "Space Combat. Reborn" they are not just talking out their ♥♥♥. They delivered on that promise. Check it out.

Each mission varies up the scenario to avoid repetetiveness: protecting a fleet, taking out a ship in particular (or protecting it), taking out incoming torpedos, loss of missile systems. Just a tip: press the camera button (default is 'C') to go into first person. You have to do this for both your fighter and the Strike Suit, otherwise you're in first person in fighter mode and third person in Strike mode. It makes the fighting a lot more intense and increases that sense of inertia.Incredibly fun; highly recommended; intense dogfighting on dogfighting action; buy it now.

ry 10, 2014
												Strike Suit: Zero is an awesome space fighting simulator that scratches an itch that few other games in recent times have.The story is told sparsely, which can be good or bad depending upon how focused you want to stay on the gameplay. The dual-nature of the Strike Suit is the central focus of the game, and it really does change combat completley when the ship transforms.You're given the option to unlock new weapons as you progress through the campaign which can also turn the tide in combat drastically. For most missions, you're locked to the strike suit (despite having unlocked other fighters) for the first playthrough. After the initial playthrough, the other fighters become unlocked and you can have another go at the level in a different ship if you so wish.The difficulty curve is fairly consistent, though the final level is just stupidly designed and plain boring. If you're not an utter completionist, leave the game at the second to last level and call that it.The Heroes of the Fleet DLC adds a new ship (the Marauder) and some new combat scenarios in the training simulator. Like the main campaign, the final level is horribly designed and gets to be an unfun grind session retry after retry. Up until then, the few missions in HotF are quite enjoyable and a nice change of pace.Ultimately, a great game marred by poor game design in the later levels in the developer's attempt to artificially ramp up difficulty.

ry 21, 2014
												An old school space sim with new mechanics.Strike Suit Zero is one of the early titles developped for the Oculus Rift but if you aren't that lucky yet, don't worry this game is still great.The universe is very immersive, with it's great open spaces and impressive color palette, the game is visually striking. But it does not end there, there is full support for any type of control method (Mouse+Keyboard, Gamepad, Joystick+Keyboard, HOTAS) and the button mapping is really intuitive (just be sure to select Joystick+Keyboard when playing with a HOTAS). However, when it comes to controlling ships, there's not much to choose from. Being a recruit you'll start with a standard fighter then shortly after you'll unlock the Strike Suit and further down some other 2 ships bringing it to a total of four ships to choose from, which is not much. But the game being named Strike Suit Zero, you already guessed what the main ship will be. It's main feature is that is can transform into a Transformer like mech and fire lock on missiles and heavy caliber both using Flux as energy, this Flux can be regenerated over time and be destroying enemy targets. So yeah, it's pretty badass. But the game does not let you be badass for long as the didfficulty of missions ramp up very quickly and the ally AI is utterly useless, forcing you to always be at your best to triumph. The old school difficulty also applies to the ranking system, if you do as you are told you might get a medal, but if you do everyones job you'll earn silver or gold. Keep in mind that there is Platinum above and since you've already won the battle to yourself there is not much left to do!Anyway, besides its frustrating difficulty Strike Suit Zero is a fantastic experience and a worthy one if you want to prepare for StarCitizen later this year (press time). With it's challenging but rewarding gameplay, this is a game that I recommend.

4, 2013
												Strike Suit Zero is influenced heavily by the classics. The ship design takes inspiration from Macross, Homeworld and Gundam, and the gameplay borrows elements from Freespace, Wing Commander and the X-Wing series. It makes a solid attempt at reintroducing what seems to be a lost genre, then makes an even bolder attempt at  adding to it. This is definitely a game for  fans of the aforementioned titles, and is highly recommended as a foreword for anyone who were to explore the mecha or space combat genres.

er 16, 2016
												Note: This is my impression after playing the base game without DLC or the Director's Cut, depending on the changes in the Director's Cut, some of these complaihnts may have been resolved.A space game in the vein of games like Star Wars: Rouge Squadron or Star Wars: X-Wing Alliance.  Due to the lack of games in this genre lately, I was greatly looking forward to this when I first heard of it.  Unfortunately, it didn't quite meet the mark.  The story starts out farcical, becomes mediocre, and then decides to be incomplete and farcical again on the final level.  When I first started playing, the controls felt too sensitive for me to fly straight, but this was solved by turning up the blind spot on the controls.  The difficulty spikes a couple times throughout the game, typically due to the targeting system not highlighting the targets you want it to in some levels, the ease of having your vision obstructed by explosions or damage preventing you from visually locating important objectives, or the dense, hyper-accurate turret concentrations on carriers.  The game also leaves you to figure out which weakpoints on large craft are actually important to kill in order to not fail the mission instead of telling you what the symbols mean.  It took me a while to come to the realization that the Strike Suit was mostly useful for its ability to kill massed enemies or bombard targets from beyond your normal range.  Also, collisions deal fixed damage regardless of speed or impact angle, which can frequently result in your instantaneous loss of all your shields from drifting too close to something while trying to kill a target.  Also, I found that it was necessary to rebind most of the weapon control keys to something else in order to not keep hitting the wrong button accidentally.Strike Suit Zero generally manages to be a game from a dead genre that reminds you that you want more games in the genre, but rarely manages to be even average at what it tries to do.

												Like the IGN review below, it IS a unique blend of arcade combat mechanics with good ole' fashion space combat simulation movement. The difficulty spikes greatly within two missions, and the battles can be very frantic to the point of being distracted by EVERYTHING on screen. 2, 2014
												I really want to recommend this game. I really do. But I can't. While it is fun to play, there's a few poins that, in my opinion, reduce the fun significantly.+ Gameplay is fun (most of the time).+ Graphics and sounds are great.+ Mouse/Keyboard controls are responsive and intuitive.- Playing with controller is difficult. I have an XBox360 controller for windows. The left stick is for rolling the ship (pretty useless), the right stick is for gearing. I'd rather have it the other way round. Since you also shoot with the right hand, I play the entire game with the right hand. And there seems to be no way to change that. Thus I resorted to mouse and keyboard.- You get additional fighters during the game, and you get a "choose your ship" screen. However, even if you already have other fighters, you can't choose freely. Most of the time, you're stuck with the Strike Suit.- The Strike Suit is annoying. You play it in pursuit mode most of the time, meaning it's basically a mediocre fighter. The standard fighter you get in the beginning has more firepower. When you magically charged your Flux bar by killing enemy ships, you get a short moment of the Suit's "glory". The Suits cannons are useless and effective only against enemy fighters. When attacking a capital ship's turrets, it likes to target turrets that are on the other side of the ship (and thus can't be hit) or the ship itself (for which it has way too little firepower).- Attacking capital ships is hard, even in easy mode. You get barraged with plasma cannons, beam cannons and flak, which can tear you apart within seconds. Which is why I never made it past mission 8. The bloody carrier is too much for the flimsy Strike Suit. Especially since there are no other friendly fighters, this it focusses all of its attention at me.- I'm not exactly fond of vocals in background music.

ry 10, 2014
												Strike Suit: Zero is an awesome space fighting simulator that scratches an itch that few other games in recent times have.The story is told sparsely, which can be good or bad depending upon how focused you want to stay on the gameplay. The dual-nature of the Strike Suit is the central focus of the game, and it really does change combat completley when the ship transforms.You're given the option to unlock new weapons as you progress through the campaign which can also turn the tide in combat drastically. For most missions, you're locked to the strike suit (despite having unlocked other fighters) for the first playthrough. After the initial playthrough, the other fighters become unlocked and you can have another go at the level in a different ship if you so wish.The difficulty curve is fairly consistent, though the final level is just stupidly designed and plain boring. If you're not an utter completionist, leave the game at the second to last level and call that it.The Heroes of the Fleet DLC adds a new ship (the Marauder) and some new combat scenarios in the training simulator. Like the main campaign, the final level is horribly designed and gets to be an unfun grind session retry after retry. Up until then, the few missions in HotF are quite enjoyable and a nice change of pace.Ultimately, a great game marred by poor game design in the later levels in the developer's attempt to artificially ramp up difficulty.

												Trying to play this on a gamepad is just pointless as the controls there are far too sensitive, making you unable to shoot the broad side of a barn. Weapons are pretty easy to use.All in all, it's an....OK game at best. If you want a simple space shooter (emphasis on simple) then go for it. But in all honesty, I wouldn't recommend. There are other games out there that do it better.

												Strike Suit Zero is influenced heavily by the classics. The ship design takes inspiration from Macross, Homeworld and Gundam, and the gameplay borrows elements from Freespace, Wing Commander and the X-Wing series. It makes a solid attempt at reintroducing what seems to be a lost genre, then makes an even bolder attempt at  adding to it. This is definitely a game for  fans of the aforementioned titles, and is highly recommended as a foreword for anyone who were to explore the mecha or space combat genres.

												Those who grew up watching Japanese mecha-themed anime (like anything out of the Gundam universe) will enjoy this game for it almost-perfectly captures the sense of overwhelming power and superiority one might get when piloting the proverbial weaponized suit. That feature alone can carry this game to a "good" rating from most fans of anime and the space combat genre. y 4, 2014
												This is one of the most satisfying games that I have ever played. I am a fan of mech anime and an even greater fan of Star Wars, so this game was everything that I could have ever hoped for. Gameplay-wise, the controls are smooth to the point where you wouldn't even know that this is an indie game. The missions are a pretty decent length, with action over at every moment. I can't say that I really feel for the characters, but that wasn't what I bought the game for. If you are hoping for story, do not come any further, However, if you are hoping for action packed, literally explosive awesomeness, come much further! The battles in this game are spectacular. Instead of just shoting the capital ships in any random spot, the game urges you to go for many of the weak points and weapons that bristle of each of them. As for graphics, this may not be The Last of Us, but the graphics are good enough to make for a beautiful game at every moment. The backgrounds are spectacular and gorgeous, with vibrant shades of colors, the best probably being the shades of purple and blue. When it comes to the soundtrack, Paul Ruskay and Kokia di an amazing job, with the ambiance of the game enhanced tenfold by the fastpaced songs. This game is definately worth the price, as well as the counterpart, Strike Suit Infinity. I have not bought a PC gaming controller, so I have no idea what the difference in playability between the two formats are.

												I did not recommend this game for a few reasons:First reason: No multiplayer. I think this game, with tweaking, could be good for multiplayer, but that doesn't seem to be on the horizon yet. However, if you're more of a single-player type person, this point need not apply to you.Second reason: Does not offer a demo. At least what I could find. This game, at the time of this writing, is on sale %75, and I bought the entire Strike Suit Zero Mega Bundle for $9.99. However, that's ten bucks I could have saved had I tried a demo first.Third reason: Not what I thought it was going to be like. Let me elaborate on this a little. First, it was my clumsy fault that I didn't notice that this game didn't support multiplayer. Some of you may remember playing a little Microsoft Studios game called Freelancer, which was an amazing spaceflight game. If you're looking for a game like that, this isn't it. I completed the first mission, and sadly to say I got kinda bored; too bored in fact to finish the second mission.Overall, the game and its graphics are nice. I wish I had a nicer graphics card to take advantage of the wonderful effects I could see in the trailers. However, the gameplay is very repetitive with little reward.

er 13, 2013
												Best mech combat simulator/space flight sim since Zone of the Enders. Gameplay is fast and fluid, offering easy of entry and an adequate difficulty curve as the game progresses. The story serves as little more than a backdrop for the absolutely massive space battles, but to be fair, did you really look into this game for a deep and thought provoking story, or just because you wanted to feel like a badass mech pilot? My only complaint is that sometimes tracking the location of your highlighted target can get difficult in the more frenzied encounters since the directional arrow highlighting it's location is the exact same color as all the other high priority target indicators on the HUD, (of which there will be many in later missions). It makes manually prioritizing your targets somewhat annoying, but not game-breaking in any way.

er 13, 2013
												I was a big Freespace and Starlancer player back when those games were popular. I was also big into Star Fox and its Nintendo 64 counterpart, in addition to an unhealthy addicted to Earthsiege, Starsiege, and the Mechwarrior series. Suffice to say that I love space combat games and sims, and it is a genre that has sadly lacked any real entries over the last decade to speak of. Strike Suit Zero fills that niche very nicely.When I started SSZ and began playing, it took a little bit of time to re-acquire the whole 'flying in space with a mouse and keyboard' feeling, but once I got the hang of it, it felt as natural as ever. The controls are nice and tight and there isn't a lot of slop. The graphics are polished but the animations during cutscenes can be a little janky sometimes. Voice acting is of far better quality than I would have expected - if you think the voiceovers are going to be as bad as, say, X3, you're wrong. Egosoft could take a note from this game. Graphics and style are overall awesome. I love the depth-of-field/blurring effect when boosting through space in cockpit view. My only gripes - the HUD situation sucks. Honestly. I hate that it's a bar at the top of the screen. It's jarring and unnatural; I would have preferred the HUD to be integrated into the cockpit in first-person view and at the sides or bottom of the screen in third-person. My other gripe - and this is going to be kind of an assanine gripe, as it centers around a key concept in the game - is the strike suit. I hate the strike suit. It just feels like a gimmicky, juvenile anime trope. I've never enjoyed mecha anime and I've never enjoyed humanoid mechs. I've always preferred the gritty down-to-earth mechs of later BattleTech and the hercs of the Earthsiege universe, they just seem more probable and more likely to exist. But I guess it's more a matter of taste, really. In gameplay the Strike Suit mode is very helpful and incredibly powerful - you can lock on to an insane number of enemies and launch cluster rockets that obliterate everything, not to mention the big giant plasma shotgun thing that wrecks face. It's definitely fun. It's use is balanced out nicely by flux mechanic, and I have not really felt the game get easier as a result of having the strike suit. The only real gameplay-related gripe that I have about it is that in strike suit mode you are forced into third person view. I hate that.It's a hard game, too. Really hard. It goes easy on you at first, but once you get your first strike suit, all bets are off. In particular the first level that takes place in a nebula is difficult (due to the fact that sensors, radar, and lockon missiles do not work- you have to rely on dumbfire rockets and visual sight). I love difficult and challenging games. The good:- Difficult- Beautiful visuals and style- Interesting concept in the strike suit- Unlockable ships and progression- Variety in space environments keeps things from getting stale- Feels like a natural progression of the space shooter genre- Music is very catchy- Voiceovers aren't half bad- Price- IndieThe bad- HUD design and placement is awkward- Music can be repetitive at times- Strike suit... mainly on aesthetic grounds- Forced third-person view in strike suit mode- Makes you wish for a modern FreespaceThis game gets 4 out of 5 cookies from me! I look forward to the next game these guys put out. I hope they keep this genre alive and renew interest in it.

, 2014
												In a word: forgettable.Ship unlocks don't carry forward to new missions, only previous missions - and there's no real reason to replay them.Side objectives - which are your sole source of basic upgrades (armor, shields, etc) - are only gained from completing side objectives, but with no radar, it's hard to pick out side objectives from the swarm of angry arrows swirling around the edge of your screen - nevermind that you must cycle target priorities until what you want pops up. This is especially agonizing as many side objectives are "stop all the torpedoes"; there are no audio or visual warnings for when torpedoes are launched, so unless you are constantly mashing 'F' to see if any are in-flight, you have absolutely no way to tell - and if even one hits, the side objective is failed...but it gets even worse! When you fail a torpedo side objective, you don't even receive a notification - so you don't even know you failed it until you've sunk ~15 - 20 minutes into a mission and see the results screen. On top of that, on every single mission that has a "torpedoes" side objective, you are required to constantly monitor corvettes, capital ships, and fighters - which you cannot really find unless you set your target priority to each in sequence by tapping 'T'...but since there's no warning when torpedoes are fired, you have to constantly cycle target priorities and mash 'F'...and then you find out 20 minutes later when you've cleared the mission (hopefully) that one single torpedo must have snuck past ya - no unlock for you!At one point I was boosting away from an enemy cruiser to let my shields recharge - note that this was a good 14 minutes into a mission - and I was abruptly greeted by a "MISSION FAILED. YOU WENT AWOL. EVERYTHING BLEW UP. EARTH BLEW UP. ALL THE PUPPIES DIED. GAME OVER." screen. There was no warning, no audio or visual queue that I was getting close to the edge of the zone like a better game would do, NO - it just springs a "GAME OVER" on you.Your AI allies are comparitively crippled, dealing significantly less damage and having less hull/shields than enemies. They also pretty much suck at covering you when you're in a slower craft, like the bomber you are required to fly in a few missions.While the ship agility is fine for open space where there aren't really any obstacles, the last stage will have you smashing your face through your screen trying to guide your ship through 9 minutes of obstacles inside a tunnel.Altogether it's not a terrible game, it's just underwhelmingly 'meh'. I plowed through it in probably < 8 hours on normal and do not care to play it any further. The issues mentioned above are pretty darn pervasive and aggravating throughout the course of the campaign.
